title: scientists unlock secret looking 30 years younger skin deep
story: Human skin cells donated from 38 and 53-year-olds have been reversed in age by 30 years, in a breakthrough that could open the door to regenerative medicine.Scientists at the Babraham Institute, a life sciences research institute in Cambridge, showed that the rejuvenated cells behaved more like youthful cells and helped to close wounds more quickly.The team adapted a Nobel Prize-winning technique, which allows skin cells to be reprogrammed back to blank-slate stem cells, using a special soup of proteins present at the early stages of embryonic development.In the new experiment, scientists halted this reprogramming before the cell entirely lost its identity, making the cells biologically younger, yet still able to perform as skin cells.Dr Diljeet Gill, a postdoctoral researcher at the Babraham Institute, said: “We have proved that cells can be rejuvenated without losing their function and that rejuvenation looks to restore some function to old cells.“The fact that we also saw a reverse of ageing indicators in genes associated with diseases is particularly promising for the future of this work.”As people age, their cells’ ability to function declines as the genetic code starts to gain errors. However, the new technique suggests that the clock could be turned back on old, failing cells.To show that the skin cells had been rejuvenated, the researchers looked for two measures of cellular age. The first is the epigenetic clock. Over time, chemical tags get attached to the genetic code and this accumulation can be measured as an indicator of age.The second is the transcriptome, the gene readouts produced by the cell, which falter over time.By these two measures, the reprogrammed cells matched the profile of cells that were 30 years younger compared to reference data sets. The cells were found to produce far more collagen, and moved to the sites of wounds faster than unprogrammed cells.The team also found that their method worked on genes linked to age-related diseases and symptoms, such as the APBA2 gene associated with Alzheimer’s disease, and the MAF gene with a role in the development of cataracts.Prof Wolf Reik, a group leader in Babraham’s epigenetics research programme, said: “This work has very exciting implications. Eventually, we may be able to identify genes that rejuvenate without reprogramming, and specifically target those to reduce the effects of ageing.“This approach holds promise for valuable discoveries that could open up an amazing therapeutic horizon.”The research was published in the journal eLife.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Dozens feared dead in rocket strike on Kramatorsk railway station Boris Becker found guilty on four counts under Insolvency ActRussian missile that struck Kramatorsk train station daubed with &#39for the children&#39Politics latest news: Rishi Sunak may have broken ministerial codeWatch: US fighter in Ukraine issues &#39plea for help&#39 for more weapons to combat RussiaMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: strange end did go wrong marble arch mound
story: On a drizzly April morning, the scaffolders have nearly finished taking down the Marble Arch Mound. They swarm like termites over the sides of the structure in their orange high-vis jackets, calling gleefully to each other in that shouty argot only scaffolders speak. The final posts are being slipped from their fixings the last pins are being loosened. Where once there was a mound, soon there will be only the Arch, standing naked and alone on its roundabout.As London’s strangest tourist attraction, with the possible exception of M&ampM’s World, recedes into the rear-view mirror, we can view it more clearly for what it was: a £6 million Covid fever dream, in which a middling concept was compounded by meddling, poor decisions and excessive haste. The results were naff, embarrassing and in the finest British tradition of this kind of thing, extremely funny. You can sort of see where Westminster Council got the idea. West London tourist numbers had slumped alarmingly during the pandemic. If there is one thing visitors around the world can agree on, it is that they like going up tall things to gaze down on the city. What are Primrose Hill and Parliament Hill, after all, if not aspirational mounds? The Shard is a kind of pointy mound, the Millennium Dome a wide and squat mound, the London Eye a high-concept circular and motorised mound. But the principle is the same. Marble Arch sits at the confluence of Oxford Street, the Edgware Road and Hyde Park. In theory it is not a bad viewing spot, especially if you like gazing down on Lebanese restaurants and Primark. Build a mound, the thinking went, and tourists would be drawn to the area, retailers would enjoy a boost and valuable column inches would be generated. In autumn 2020, Dutch design firm MVRDV was asked to draw up plans for the Mound. Their initial plans incorporated Marble Arch itself, before English Heritage and Historic England kiboshed that idea. The site had to move and become smaller, with steeper sides harder for trees to sit on. MVRDV, in their telling, were excluded from the execution of the project: a process made more difficult by Covid restricting travel between Britain and Holland. Even as it was being made, the Mound looked odd. The mock-ups promised a lush woodland paradise in central London. What emerged was a bulky and inelegant structure, clad in threadbare brown-green turf with a few spindly trees and surrounded by levels of scaffolding normally associated with the construction of a cathedral. “I live nearby and I first went along sort of out of bemusement,” says Dan Barker, a local resident, who booked a ticket (£7.50) for the opening day. “I couldn’t understand why they had chosen to spend what was obviously a large amount of money on a temporary structure at a time when scaffolding was at its highest cost in living memory. As the launch day approached, I could see it was nowhere near what the original designs had depicted.”He was not alone. The council was at least right about the press coverage. The problems began almost at once. The Mound was met with almost universal derision when it opened last July, variously called a “monstrosity” and a “disgrace”. Trees tumbled from the sides, unable to cope with the heat.Almost as soon as it opened, the Mound was temporarily closed. The council said it was to make improvements, but it seemed more like the sheepish panic of an organisation managing a fiasco. Even the decision to close was a mistake, says Barker, because it had started to draw visitors as a so-bad-it’s-good cult hit. When it opened again, it was without the same momentum. Barker paid for another ticket, for the final slot on the final day in January, but he needn’t have bothered. By the end they were giving them away for free. “The slot was for 10pm and there were all these people competing to be the last person on it. Strange to the end.” In August, Melvyn Caplan, the deputy leader of Westminster council, resigned. Professionally speaking, it can’t have been the hill he wanted to die on. Having initially said the Mound would cost £2 million to build, Westminster Council had admitted that the figure was in fact £6 million. The dismantling alone has apparently cost £600,000. The council’s projections estimated that it would bring in more than £2 million in revenue, with £1.5 million raised from a quarter of a million tickets and most of the rest from sponsorship, as well as food and drink sales and merchandise. At the time of writing, the merchandise had yet to see the light of day. (If you know of the whereabouts of any, please email.)A report in October said that senior leaders had hid details and lied about fundraising efforts. Debbie Jackson, the council’s executive director for growth, planning and housing, stuck to her guns, citing 250,000 visitors – not all of them in hysterics. There is more we have not been told chiefly how the costs trebled yet 44 council staff from Westminster were listed the other day among those making more than £100,000 a year.One day the Mound will give up its secrets, but compared to the money that was torched on PPE and Test and Trace, £6 million for a naff and misconceived tourist attraction seems like a bargain. If the council had deliberately spent the same money on a scheme to provide people around the country with a much-needed pandemic laugh, along with a sense of relief that they had not been involved in this catastrophe themselves, it would have been cheap. If there’s one thing that brings people together more than a hill with a view, it’s schadenfreude. With the worst days of the pandemic behind us, the slowly-shrinking Mound stands as a living monument to the psychological toll of coronavirus. Marble Arch was built by John Nash as a tribute to the monarchy at the height of empire. The Mound was a far more relatable piece of public sculpture. We might not all have spent £6 million of public money on a doomed 25m horticultural scaffold, but it was far from the most eccentric scheme cooked up in the strange circumstances of the past two years. There was a little Mound in all of us.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Dozens feared dead in rocket strike on Kramatorsk railway station Boris Becker found guilty on four counts under Insolvency ActRussian missile that struck Kramatorsk train station daubed with &#39for the children&#39Politics latest news: Rishi Sunak may have broken ministerial codeWatch: US fighter in Ukraine issues &#39plea for help&#39 for more weapons to combat RussiaMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: waistline less half height magic ratio good health
story: Keep your waistline to less than half of your height to stay in good health, new NHS advice warns.Draft guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) encourages everyone to get out a tape measure and tackle stomach fat, in order to cut the risk of a host of health problems.Until now, its advice has suggested that Body Mass Index - which measures the mass and height of a person - is enough to assess whether weight is healthy or not.However, the updated guidance suggests that abdominal fat carries specific risks. For example, a 5ft 4in female with waist circumference of 29in would have a healthy ratio, but 32in would push them into the unhealthy range.A man who is 5ft 10in would be at increased health risks with a 36in waist.The guidance urges health professionals to be “sensitive and positive” when starting conversations about the risks of excess weight, and to ask permission before raising the matter.It follows research which has linked abdominal fat to cancer, with visceral fat around the internal organs linked to a number of diseases.The guidance says anyone with a BMI below 35 kgm squared (the threshold for severe obesity) should use their waist measurement as a simple guide to see if their weight is healthy.Dr Paul Chrisp, the director of the centre for guidelines at Nice, said: “Our updated draft guideline offers people a simple and effective way of measuring their weight so they can understand the factors that could impact on their health and take action to address them.“Our committee found that a clear benefit of using the waist-to-height ratio is that people can easily measure it themselves, interpret the results, and seek medical advice if they are at increased health risk.”The guideline says a healthy waist to height ratio is 0.4 to 0.49, indicating no increased health risks.A ratio of 0.5 to 0.59 puts people at increased risk of health issues, while 0.6 or more puts them at the highest risk of health problems.Two in three adults in the UK are overweight or obese, with rates of obesity having doubled since the 1990s.Nice said using the waist-to-height ratio, in conjunction with BMI, can help to provide a practical estimate of “central adiposity” - the accumulation of fat around the abdomen - to help to assess and predict health risks, such as type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure or heart disease.Its experts added the waist-to-height ratio to its draft guideline after looking at evidence from several studies which showed that, alongside BMI, it could be used to assess and predict weight-related conditions in all ethnicities and sexes.It follows a long debate over the value of BMI, which is a less accurate measure of healthy weight in those who are extremely muscular.BMI does not take into account muscle mass, bone density, overall body composition, meaning that athletes with low levels of body fat are often classed as obese.Tam Fry, from the National Obesity Forum, said: “Nice has finally endorsed a measurement which obesity specialists have advocated since 2015.”The new draft guidance says BMI should be interpreted “with caution” especially in those aged 65 and over, as well as in those with high muscle mass.It suggests that measurements are a more “practical” way to make an assessment.Prof Rachel Batterham, a consultant in obesity, diabetes and endocrinology and a guideline committee member, said: “Increased fat in the abdomen increases a person’s risk of developing several life-limiting diseases including type 2 diabetes and heart disease. Waist-to-height ratio is a simple, easy to use measure that identifies people who are at increased health risk and would benefit from weight management support to improve their health.”NHS figures show obesity was linked to more than one million hospital admissions in 201920 - a 17 per cent rise in a year.Government estimates suggest obesity is costing the NHS more than £6.1 billion annually, with £27 billion costs for wider society.Dr Nivedita Aswani, a consultant paediatrician specialising in diabetes and weight management at Sheffield Children’s Hospital, said: “A waist measurement can be taken independently by a young person in the security of their own home, or by a carer for their child. A waist measurement of more than half of a person's height, is an indication of greater risk.Young people should be encouraged to seek advice about weight management, and sensitively supported to lower their risk of developing these conditions, and to improve overall health and wellbeing.”The draft guidance states: “It is important for healthcare professionals to ask for permission before any discussions linked to overweight, obesity and central adiposity, and to discussing them in a sensitive and positive manner.“This is because the substantial stigma associated with obesity has negative effects on people’s mental and physical health, which can lead to further weight gain and make people less likely to engage with healthcare practitioners. Particular sensitivity is needed about the possible negative impact on people with conditions such as eating disorders or disordered eating.“Using words and language that avoid stigma and prejudice can help people to engage in conversations about obesity, and encourage weight loss,” it adds.A consultation on the proposed recommendations is taking place until Wednesday, May 11 2022.More from NewsBoris Becker found guilty on four counts under Insolvency ActRussian missile that struck Kramatorsk train station daubed with &#39for the children&#39Russia-Ukraine latest news: Dozens feared dead in rocket strike on Kramatorsk railway station Politics latest news: Rishi Sunak may have broken ministerial codeWatch: US fighter in Ukraine issues &#39plea for help&#39 for more weapons to combat RussiaMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

news politics eric-pickles-moans-grenfell-inquiry-"Lord Pickles tells Grenfell Tower fire inquiry he has a "busy day"ByDan BloomOnline Political EditorLuke OReilly:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A top Tory complained he had an “extremely busy day” while being questioned over the Grenfell Tower fire - then got the death toll wrong.Eric Pickles made the extraordinary double gaffe while giving evidence at the public inquiry into the west London disaster that killed  people in June . Lord Pickles, who led a crackdown on “red tape” while in charge of the housing department from  to , admitted ministers should have acted more on warnings before the blaze during two days of questioning. But on his second day he snapped to lead counsel to the inquiry Richard Millett QC: By all means sir, feel free to ask me as many questions as you like. “But could I respectfully remind you that you did promise that we would be away this morning and I have changed my schedules to fit this in. I do have an extremely busy day meeting people. But this is more important than anything - but I would urge you to use your time wisely.  Lord Pickles later apologised for “any way I seemed discourteous”, adding: “As soon as I left the room I took the decision to cancel everything. “This is more important than anything I’m doing and I apologise… I fully understand that you’re doing a proper job.” But at the end of his evidence, he tripped up separately - appearing to mistake the death toll for that of Hillsborough, which until recently was . The toll from the  football ground disaster rose to  last year after a coroner’s ruling on the death of fan Andrew Devine. Lord Pickles referred to coroneraposs recommendations after the  Lakanal House fire in south London, which killed six people and injured  more. The first report from the Grenfell Inquiry found lessons from Lakanal fire had not been learned by the time of the Grenfell disaster eight years later.  He said: “It comes down to Michelleand to the nameless  people who were killed in the Grenfell fire. Itaposs them who we should think about when weaposre arguing the toss. Ultimately, as Iaposve said earlier, the dead deserve the dignity of being remembered by name and the dead deserve the dignity of a solution.”Lord Pickles was also chairman of the Conservative Party from  to .He made the mistake at the end of his evidence while answeringthere was anything he would have done dferently. After Lakanal, he said, “maybe I should have put in the letter the simple sentence aposand I accept the coroneraposs recommendationsapos - would that have changed things ”. But he added: “I donapost think it would have made any dference whatsoever.  There was a kind of mindset that existed in parts of the department that just simply ignored what was happening, made a view about what we were and came to it. Askedthe department should have “done more” to take on the lessons from Lakanal he replied: “Oh, definitely”. He added it was a personal failing on his part, “on the basis that I’m responsible for everything. The fact that I didn’t know about it, that no one briefed me… is no reasonable excuse, because ultimately it is always my fault.” But he also slammed firms that used flammable cladding, saying: “The conditions existed that there were people putting things in, into  and the like, that were combustible. “The idea to me is: how would anybody ever want to do that  How would they ever think it was a good idea ” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Eric PicklesConservative PartyPublic inquiryRed tapePolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. title: family firm rishi sunaks non
story: Exclusive: Family firm of Rishi Sunaks non-dom status we won £m in taxpayer-funded dealsA Mirror investigation has found the Murty family’s vast Infosys business made tens of millions of pounds from British taxpayer-funded contracts, some since Mr Sunak became Chancellor in Rishi Sunak with his we Akshata Murty Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesByNick SommerladInvestigations Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments The Mirror has uncovered details of a string of lucrative public sector contracts won by Infosys, the Indian IT firm which is part owned by Chancellor Rishi Sunak ’s we.Akshata Murty pays £, a year to secure her non-domiciled tax status, which allows her to avoid paying taxes on millions of pounds earned from her near-% stake in Infosys overseas. Labour leader Keir Starmer condemned her “breathtaking hypocrisy” for claiming non-dom status while living in Downing Street with a Chancellor husband who has hiked taxes for millions of ordinary people. While the Tories force people to choose between eating or heating, the millionaire Chancellor with four luxury homes parades his wealth on social media, posing in £ slider shoes before the last Budget and with a £ “smart mug” the year before. His brutal .% hike in National Insurance came into force this week. Our investigation found the Murty family’s vast Infosys business made tens of millions of pounds from British taxpayer-funded contracts, some since Mr Sunak became Chancellor in . Since , Infosys has earned £million working for the Care Quality Commission, the regulator of UK care homes. In , it won a £m contract with the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, and this year secured a £m IT contract from the Tory-run East Sussex County Council. Infosys is among companies which shared £m in public sector contracts between  and . It was one of  suppliers in a £m deal with Transport for London in , at a time when Prime Minister Boris Johnson was Mayor of London.And it was one of nine partners in a £m contract with Tory-run Westminster City Council last year. Angela Rayner, Labour’s Deputy Leader, told the Mirror: “The British public deserve answers. The Government is already awash with Tory cronyism. Now it seems the Chancellor’s close family are personally benefiting from lucrative public contracts. Rishi Sunak must come clean about these business interests and any potential conflicts.”And Ed Miliband said the Chancellor should issue an “explanation” about his we’s tax status. Speaking to Sky News, the Shadow Secretary of State for Climate Change said: “He is the UK Chancellor asking people to pay more in taxes. “Is it right that his immediate family is sheltering from UK taxes  I think Rishi Sunak and his family should reflect on that. Non-dom status is legal but I think we should be clear that non-dom status is used to... pay less tax than you otherwise would.”  Christine Jardine, Lib Dem Treasury spokeswoman, said: “Infosys benefiting from millions in UK Government contracts raises serious questions. It is wrong that profits making their way from these contracts into the Chancellor’s household don’t face their fair share of UK tax.” Ms Murty, who wed Mr Sunak in , is one of Britain’s richest women, her stake of almost % in Infosys worth a reported £m. Earnings from its UK public sector projects contributed to global Infosys revenues of £.bn last year, which earned profits of £.bn. It is estimated Ms Murty earns more than £m in idends from her stake, but she is not domiciled in the UK for tax purposes. On Wednesday, her spokeswoman said because she is an Indian citizen and India does not allow dual citizenship, then “according to British law, Ms Murty is treated as non-domiciled for UK tax purposes”.  The spokeswoman admitted yesterday that Ms Murty pays £, a year for her non-dom status. And Professor of Accounting Richard Murphy said: “She is only non-domiciled because she asked to be so.” There is no suggestion of wrongdoing. But, as a non-dom, Ms Murty does not need to pay tax on idends from overseas firms such as Infosys. It was founded by her dad Narayana Murty, has its HQ in India and is listed on the Indian and New York stock exchanges. If taxed on £m of Infosys idends in the UK, Ms Murty would pay more than £m, while in India she would pay as little as %, or £.m. Tax Justice UK executive director, Robert Palmer, said: “Ordinary people who face an increase to their national insurance contributions this week will be shocked to learn the Chancellor’s own we is a non-dom. This status could potentially save her substantial amounts of tax. The Government should end tax loopholes such as non-dom status and make sure those who have wealth pay their share.” Labour leader Mr Starmer said: “The Chancellor has imposed tax rise after tax rise on working people and he’s said time and again there’s no alternative, we’ve got no option. If it now transpires that his we has used schemes to reduce her own tax then that’s breathtaking hypocrisy and is more evidence of just how out of touch this Chancellor is.”The Prime Minister dodged questions about Ms Murty’s tax affairs. He said: “I think it is very important in politics,you possibly can, to try and keep people’s families out of it.” Last week, Mr Sunak objected to questions over Infosys’s business in Russia, while telling UK firms to “think very carefully” about making investments potentially beneficial to Putin regime.He said he found criticism of his we “very upsetting”. It has since emerged that Infosys is closing its Russian office.  Mr Sunak last month delivered a Spring Statement which failed to tackle the cost of living crisis. He and his family live in a flat above No, but they also own a £m mews property in Kensington, a flat in Old Brompton Road, a £m, -acre country pile in his Yorkshire constituency, and a lavish apartment in Santa Monica, Calornia. After the Chancellor was snapped filling up a car – not his, but a vehicle belonging to a supermarket worker – after the Spring Statement, Mr Sunak said he drove an old VW golf. He failed to mention he had use of at least three others, a Range Rover, a top-of-the-range Lexus, and a BMW. The Mirror has contacted the Treasury, Infosys and Ms Murty for comment. title: pm refuses accept responsibility brits
story: PM refuses to accept responsibility as Brits struggle to pay for fuel and foodBoris Johnson accepted today that the poorest households in Britain were having to choose between heating and eating. What he refused to accept was responsibilityBoris Johnson is refusing to accept responsibility for the cost of living crisis Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |comments Britain is experiencing the worst fall in living standards for more than  years.Families are struggling to pay their fuel bills and put food on their table. The situation is so bad that police chiefs are warning of a crime spree as desperate parents steal to feed their children. Boris Johnson accepted today that the poorest households were having to choose between heating and eating. What he refused to accept was responsibility.It was his Government that cut Universal Credit, slashed benefits and raised taxes to their highest level since the Second World War. When so many are below the breadline, you would think any Government would do everything in its power to alleviate their plight. It is actually doing very little. Only the Tories could be resigned to so many people living in hardship and only the Tories could be so unwilling to do anything about it.  Virus failure Britain is now paying the price for the Government’s hasty decision to lt all Covid restrictions. Hospitals across England have declared critical emergencies because high infection rates have left them struggling to cope with an increase in admissions and staff shortages. The travel sector has also been affected, with airlines forced to cancel flights because so many crew members are off sick. Boris Johnson appears to be in denial about the situation. The Prime Minister once promised to do everything he could to control the pandemic but the latest figures show hundreds are still dying from the virus every day. People’s lives and livelihoods are at risk. We rate rats The RSPCA wants more people to adopt abandoned pet rats. Contrary to their reputation, the animals are squeaky clean, sociable and intelligent. news politics question-time-howls-laughter-energy-"Question Time: Greg Hands says energy discount isn’t a loanByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsThe government’s energy minister was on the receiving end of howls of laughter as he tried to defend a £ aposdiscountapos offered to cash-strapped Brits.The moment was captured during BBC Question Time on Thursday when he struggled to convince the audience that a £ discount to tackle the cost of living crisis wasn’t just a loan.Brits are facing an ominous hike in energy prices this year which is leading many to wonder how they are going to cope. Conservative minister Greg Hands was asked about the government’s plans to help provide greener fuels for people and he also outlined the steps that were being made to help people deal with the cost of living crisis.Mr Hands referred to a £ billion package that Chancellor Rishi Sunak revealed last February where a one-off repayable £ discount and a rebate on council tax bills would help tackle the £-a-year rise in average household’s energy bills in April. The Minister of State for Business, Energy and Clean Growth said the £ discount was not just a loan. He told the Question Time audience: The Chancellor of the Exchequer launched a really important package in February, just two months ago to deal with the rise in bills, not deal with it completely, but actually £ billion set aside, a £ discount on energy bills, a £ discount on council tax, additional funds to make sure the most vulnerable are able ... give them assistance in paying their energy.” At that point presenter Fiona Bruce jumped in saying: £ is, of course, a loan  And Mr Hands replied: It is not a loan, it is a discount, which you have to pay it back in the form of a levy. Ms Bruce persisted: But you have to pay it back, it sounds like a loan   The government minister continued: Not the inidual, it gets taken back at the point that it is levied. With laughs and shouts from the audience, Ms Bruce said to them: You are all shouting, what are you all shouting  They yelled back: It’s a loan. Mr Hands kept going: It’s taken back through a levy, it is not a loan because it does not create an obligation on the inidual to repay, it is actually a levy on the price point. He added: It is put on the price point, not on the inidual. The inidual does not have an obligation to repay. Askedpeople didnapost have to repaythey didnapost want he responded with members of the audience chuckling: No I’m not saying that.  At that point Labour MP Emily Thornberry said: Soyou don’t heat,you don’t have any heating afterwards then you don’t pay it back. It is not an obligation, said Mr Hands. These are the important things which have been announced to help people with bills. But that is dferent to the long term strategy that we have launched today with renewables, nuclear and making sure we are not increasing our imports of oil and gas. Boris Johnson has also had to defend the government over claims that the new energy strategy doesnapost help people with soaring bills.He said the strategy - which sets out aims to boost new nuclear power, offshore wind and hydrogen - is a long-term plan focusing on energy supply, undoing the mistakes of the past and taking the big decisions now. He said the Government was already doing a huge amount to help people with the immediate cost of living and of course we are going to do more. The latest investment will support research, development and deployment of cutting-edge technologies, the Government said, adding that it was also publishing a range of important documents and guidelines to support the development of these industries. A financial package, announced last Friday, includes £ million to fund low carbon hydrogen production projects, £ million towards the acceleration of Carbon Capture and StorageTechnologies, and a £. million competition for bidders to develop a UK Advanced Modular Reactor . news politics uk-energy-strategy--things-"Boris says UK wont be subjected to Putin blackmail over energyByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAfter weeks of delay and late-night tussles, Boris Johnson has published his plan to wean Britain off Russian energy without collapsing our economy.The Prime Minister has pledged to “produce vastly more hydrogen”, build “up to” one nuclear reactor per year, and “take advantage of Britain’s inexhaustible resources of wind and – yes – sunshine”. The idea is to keep energy bills under control as we end Russian oil, coal andgas imports due to the “abhorrent and illegal invasion of Ukraine ”. But under pressure from warring Tories, Mr Johnson dropped key pledges on hilltop wind farms - and is set to plough more resources into North Sea oil.He also announced no help for families’ soaring energy bills now - and nothing new for insulating homes.  The ,-word policy was still being worked out at the last minute and was published as a simple web page, with no time for fancy graphs or even a proper PDF document.But the Tony Blair Institute said “expensive, slow and risky options [have been] backed over quick, cheap and popular ones”.So what is actually in the energy strategy and what are the gaping holes he missed  Here’s what you need to know. things the government has announced ‘Up to’  nuclear reactors in  yearsThe document vows to reverse “decades” of short-sightedness, including under Tory governments, and “invest massively in nuclear power”. It aims to take one “final investment decision” on nuclear - possibly a new site at Sizewell - by  and another in the next Parliament, by . Between them these could lead to eight reactors by , it’s claimed, because there can be more than one reactor at each power station. These could be a mixture of large ‘gigawatt reactors’ and Small Modular Reactors - raising nuclear from % of our power now to % in . But there are big questions about funding and how realistic ‘one reactor a year’ actually is - more below. It’s thought the “up to” eight new reactors would go on some of the eight sites already approved to host nuclear reactors. These are Hinkley, Sizewell, Heysham, Hartlepool, Bradwell, Wylfa, Oldbury and Moorside - with Wylfa lined up for an imminent project. After that, the government will “develop a strategy” that could identy new sites that’ve never hosted a nuclear plant before. But this seems a long way off. New investment in North Sea oil - despite our green goalsThe document pledges a new round of licences to launch this Autumn for oil and gas projects in the North Sea. It claims there’s “no contradiction” between this and Britain’s pledge to reach Net Zero carbon emissions - which will be a “smooth transition, not immediate extinction”. But Rebecca Newsom of Greenpeace UK said Tories are dishing out rewards to vested interests in the nuclear and the oil and gas industries. The document insists Britain will have “reduced our gas consumption by over % by ”. And “by , we will have decarbonised our electricity system, subject to security of supply”. That’s a get-out clause - it’s understood gas could still be used in some circumstances beyond . Meanwhile the strategy leaves the door open to fracking - currently banned thanks to the  Tory manesto - after Tory MPs urged a rethink. But that door is only just open. It says while the government “remains open-minded”, the pause on fracking “continues to remain in place unless new evidence emerge”. Lots of new offshore wind power The strategy repeats Boris Johnson ’s dubious pledge to become “the Saudi Arabia of wind power” with it generating more than half our renewable energy by .That would be “up to” GW by , including “up to” GW from massive floating wind turbines. The government will cut the consent time down from four yers to one strengthen policy statements and review habitat assessments from late  to ‘reduce reams of paperwork’ on protecting wildle. But again there are questions about cash. Today’s plan highlights a £m pot to kickstart work on floating wind turbines which Boris Johnson announced in the autumn. The UK’s first floating wind farm alone, which has five turbines, cost more than that entire funding pot. Energy firm Equinor spent billion Norwegian Kroner - equivalent to around £m - on the Hywind Scotland plant  miles off the coast of Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, in . Its ft high floating turbines each weighs , tonnes and has a rotor diameter of ft - equivalent to three Nelson’s Columns stacked end to end. A five-fold rise in solar power, with relaxed planning rulesThere is currently GW of solar capacity in the UK but the cost of building it has dropped % in a decade, so the government wants a five-fold rise to GW by . For ground solar farms, ministers will consult on tearing up planning rules to tip more “in favour of development” on non-protected land. Communities would still get a say. For rooftop solar , the government has vowed to “radically simply” the planning process, launching a consultation on using “permitted development” rights. This meansyou want to put a solar  on your roof, you could do it without having to submit a full-blown planning application. The government is also “looking at” getting banks to offer low-cost finance on solar  or energy efficiency for homes. But critics say it’s not enough - more below.Hydrogen, tidal and geothermal powerThe plan promises investment in hydrogen, tidal and geothermal power - but despite chatter about this for decades it’s pretty thin on details. It simply says we will “aggressively explore renewable opportunities afforded by our geography and geology, including tidal and geothermal”. Hydrogen - which could eventually replace gas in central heating for households who don’t get a heat pump - is a bit more concrete. The plan vows to double the target for hydrogen production capacity by , to GW. But that would be “subject to affordability and value for money”. There would also be a hydrogen certication scheme by , “to demonstrate high-grade British hydrogen for export and ensure any imported hydrogen meets the same high standards”. The Tony Blair Institute claims the hydrogen strategy is “bizarre” because it would create “signicant” new demand for natural gas in the production process. … and the  gaping holes in the plan Bottling Boris Johnson scrapped onshore wind targetsAn early version of the document pledged GW of capacity from onshore wind by  and GW by  - up from GW now. But despite hilltop wind turbines being much cheaper than ones in the sea, the final document drops this target - due to a Tory tussle over the “eyesore” machines. The pledge is seriously watered down, with a promise of “no wholesale changes” to the planning system. The government will “consult” this year on “local partnerships” where “supportive” villages that agree to wind farms could get cheaper bills in . But in a victory for rural Tories it adds: “The government recognises the range of views on onshore wind. Our plans will prioritise putting local communities in control.” There’s no help for energy bills now Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng was revealing when he said: “I think the impact could be very soon. And by soon, I mean, three or four years.” The plan mentions the £ repayable rebate to energy bills, but offers nothing new, just as reports emerge that Rishi Sunak blocked a suggestion to raise it to £.Government officials insist they were never pretending this would give short-term help for bills, and it will eventually bring down costs in the long term. But the Lib Dems said: “Itaposs a disgrace that the Chancellor is refusing to offer extra help to hard pressed families facing soaring energy bills.” Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Pat McFadden added: The Tories have no plan to immediately address their cost of living crisis.He could back Labour ’s fair and funded plan for a one-off tax on the booming profits of oil and gas giants - which would reduce household bills by up to £.” There’s nothing new for insulating your homeCampaigners hit out furiously at the fact that there’s no new hard fund or target in the plan today for getting old, draughty homes insulated. Simon McWhirter of the UK Green Building Council added: Today was a chance to insulate the nation’s homes, protect us against future price hikes and tackle the painful effects of rising energy costs to households. The Government has woefully missed its opportunity.”The funding for those nuclear power stations is very murkyAs above, a big new plank of the plan is investing massively in nuclear power stations - with three funding decisions in the next two parliaments. But what’s missing is any set amount of cash promised now. And that will be hard to come by, especially as a dferent PM - Labour or Tory - could be in charge by then. The document is also full of catches and get-out clauses about the hope of building eight new nuclear reactors by . It says: “Final contracts and construction would commence when any outstanding conditions are satisfied and projects are sufficiently mature. “Any projects would be subject to a value for money assessment, all relevant approvals and future spending reviews.” Imports of Russian gas CAN continue The whole reason behind the plan is Russia ’s brutal invasion of Ukraine, and our need to cut off the “war machine” by no longer buying Russian energy.But while coal and oil imports to the UK will end by December , we’ll only wean off Russian gas “as soon as possible thereafter”. Despite % of our gas coming from Russia, sources admit the industry - already handling rocketing prices - cannot afford the sudden end of Russian gas. That’s why there is no hard target on ending our dependence on Russian gas, despite Putin’s regime being accused of war crimes. title: unused ppe bought during covid
story: Unused PPE bought during Covid pandemic up for auction for almost no moneyMillions of surplus aprons, visors, hand sanitisers and goggles which cost an estimated £, are being auctioned off - with some bids as low as £The Government scrambled to get enough PPE at the start of the pandemic Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr |commentsUnused personal protective equipment bought for hundreds of thousands of pounds is being auctioned off by the Government for as little as £. Millions of surplus aprons, visors, hand sanitisers and goggles are going under the hammer on the auction website Ramco as the Government bids to stop paying out millions of pounds of taxpayers’ cash to store stock. Labour analysis using average unit prices from the National Audit Office suggests that the Government may have shelled out more than £, for the goods at the height of the pandemic in . Ten lots of kits are now being sold with a starting price of just £ - with bidding ending on Tuesday.A -pallet lot of , goggles has a bid of £ while , aprons have an offer of £. Buyers must have their own lorry and be willing to pick up the goods from ious locations around the UK, the auction note states. It comes after Government accounts for   revealed around £. billion spent on useless protective gear has been written off.Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting said: The Conservatives wasted billions of pounds of taxpayers’ money on useless PPE that they’re now giving away for virtually nothing. If they hadn’t been so wasteful with the public’s money, the Government might not need to raise taxes on working people in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis.News of the PPE fire sale was slipped out as Parliament went into recess last week.Health Minister Edward Argar said: “To date we have achieved the sale of  million masks to two private companies, and we have other deals in the pipeline. “We are also about to launch an online auction to sell PPE, so iniduals and companies may bid for our excess stock.” He said  million visors had been recycled into food trays and surplus aprons were being turned into bin bags.  Products that cannot be recycled, sold or repurposed will be binned. Overall, the Department of Health claimed “the amount taxpayers will save from taking this decisive action would, for example, be enough to employ around , nurses for a year. Last month, MPs were told that the Government was planning to burn mountains of unusable PPE bought during the pandemic. Jonathan Marron, DHSC director general of office for health improvement and disparities, told the Commons Public Accounts Committee: Weaposre currently appointing to what are called lead waste partners, commercial firms who do this as their business who will help us recycle and weaposre also exploring using it for... waste to provide power. We think we move up to , pallets a month when we get these contracts in place, so a really signicant way of seeing recycling increase and indeed using some of the product to drive power generation. title: voters think welfare benefits should
story: Exclusive: Voters think welfare benefits should cover cost of living - think tank reportThe study by Bright Blue showed cross-party support for an increase in social security payments - but bigger backing from Labour supportersPoorer households relying on benefits should get more help, according to the study Image: Getty ImagesByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Apr |commentsVoters overwhelmingly back boosting benefits to help hard-up households cover the cost of living, a report reveals today. Seven out of  people polled backed the idea that “benefit payments should be sufficiently high to allow people to pay for their costs of living, such as housing payments, buying essential food and heating their homes”. The survey found that %of Tory voters and % of Labour supporters agreed. Two-thirds of those quizzed said it was “the Government’s responsibility to ensure that all people have financial support to meet their basic needs”. Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter But there was a sharp political ide, with % of Conservatives backing the statement, compared with % of Labour voters. Welfare payments are rising by just .% despite inflation running at .% and tipped to surge beyond % later this summer.  The research, including an Opinium survey of , adults, is published today in a report, ‘Stepping up: public attitudes to addressing the cost of living crisis’, by Tory-linked think-tank Bright Blue. The study, seen exclusively by the Mirror, says: “Our polling identies that the UK public, across political ides, supports the idea that benefit payments need to be sufficiently high to allow people to pay for their costs of living, and that the financial support provided by the Government needs to meet their basic needs.” Senior research fellow An Sarygulov said: “The Chancellor needs to stop being allergic to welfare, recognise the effectiveness of the Universal Credit system, and bring forward the next uprating of the benefits from April  for a far more substantive, effective, and targeted intervention.” A Government spokesman said: “We recognise the pressures people are facing with the cost of living, which is why we’re providing support worth £billion across the next financial year. “This includes putting an average of £, more per year into the pockets of working families via changes to Universal Credit, cutting fuel duty and helping households with their energy bills. “We have also boosted the minimum wage by more than £, a year for full-time workers and are raising National Insurance thresholds so people keep more of what they earn, while our £bn household support fund is helping the most vulnerable with essential costs.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour PartyConservative PartyPoliticsWelfare cutsBenefitsUniversal CreditCost of Living: Were Here to HelpInflationBritish economyThe economy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: my man plus size im
story: My man is plus-size and Im slim - people say our relationship is fake but I love himSienna Keera, , moved all the way from Sydney in Australia to live with her husband George Keywood in London - but while the pair are happy in their relationship they have to put up with vicious trollingSienna and George hit it off as soon as they met Image: siennakeera instagramByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Apr |commentsA woman who moved from Australia to live with her beau after sliding into his DMs has hit back at trolls who say sheaposs only with him for his money. Sienna Keera, , from Sydney, met her now-husband George Keywood after she became attracted to his character on British mockumentary People Just Do Nothing. After watching the comedy, about a pirate radio station called Kurupt FM, Sienna found she was attracted to the character Craig - who is played by George. Telling her story to Take  magazine, Sienna described him as a plus-sized man with beautul eyes. After meeting in  the pair are now married with a two-year-old son, Oliver - but they have to contend with daily trolling from people who think Sienna couldnapost possibly love George because heaposs a bigger man. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here The couple, who share snippets of their relationship on TikTok, receive comments suggesting itaposs all a publicity stunt.Sienna revealed one person said to her:Blink three timesyouaposre being kept against your will. But the trolls couldnapost be more wrong, as Sienna has revealed it was her who first approached George.As her attraction towards him grew while watching his show, she tracked him down on Instagram and decided to send him a message telling him she thought he was hilarious.To her surprise, George replied and the pair began chatting - and according to Sienna, it wasnapost long before the conversation became flirty. Sienna had been planning a trip to Europe with her friend at the time, but when her friend had to pull out of the holiday Sienna decided to visit London, Amsterdam and Paris on her own.  And she had her sights set on meeting George for the first time when she landed in the UK. Sending him a message the night before she was due to arrive in London, Sienna arranged to see George in the flesh and invited him over to her AirBnB. The next day as she tried to recover from her jetlag, Sienna recalls being fraught with nerves while waiting for George to arrive. But she says the minute she opened the door to him, she felt relaxed. The pair spent the next few days visiting the Tate Modern and having dinner while getting to know each other better. And after hitting it off immediately Sienna decided to invite George to join her for the remainder of her six-week tour of Europe.While the pair travelled around France and The Netherlands together, they began talking about how their relationship would fare long distance when Sienna ed to Australia. George was unsure about making the move down under as it would mean starting from scratch in his acting career. So after discussing it in depth, Sienna decided to uproot her le and move to London instead. When she ed to Australia, she immediately applied for a UK visa and broke the news to her parents that she was moving to London permanently. After they got over their initial shock and met George on Skype, Sienna says her mum and dad approved of their relationship. Shortly after making the move, Sienna and George took a trip to Venice, where he popped the question. Just a few months later, she fell pregnant with their first child. But still the pair have to put up with trolls saying Siennaaposs only in the relationship for the fame - and she admits George is better at dealing with it due to his background in showbiz. As time has passed Sienna has learnt how to block out the nasty comments and focuses on the many messages of support she receives. She said: Taking a chance on love like I did doesnapost always pay off – but Iaposm so grateful my leap of faith did. title: selfless mum dubbed angel helping
story: Selfless mum dubbed angel for helping others in cost-of-living nightmareKaren Noble and The Pallion Action Group make a real dference at the heart of their community, thanks to funding that you help raise by playing The Health LotteryKaren Noble is the manager of The Pallion Action GroupAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Apr “Bingo and Broth” or “Quiche and Quiz” are just two events that tempt people into Sunderland’s The Pallion Action Group – but the community centre and its friendly staff offer so much more. Manager Karen Noble is on a mission to make sure people are getting the support and benefits they need – and this is particularly important for older visitors, who might feel isolated. “It’s not just about organising activities they can get involved with: conversations might come out of that,” says Karen. “People will tell you what they’re struggling with and how you can support them. You might find out that they’ve been given an iPad but have no internet connection, or that they don’t feel safe because some kids have been throwing eggs in the streets. “We have a lot of older people who shouldbe receiving benefits but they’re not. So we want to get that message out to them. They’ll go ‘No, I’m alright’ because there is a bit of pride there – but we want to make sure they get everything they’re entitled to.”Karen is devoted to helping people in the local community because she knows what it’s like to struggle. As a young mum of two, she worked and had to battle to support her children. “I had to fight to make sure I got all the right benefits – and then people saw what I did and started coming to me for help,” says Karen. Welcome new players! If you set up a Health Lottery account between .. and .., make a first-time deposit of £. or more and apply promo code FIRST, you will receive a £. bonus in your online wallet.The bonus must be used within  days of it being received after which time it will expire. Bonus credit is fully paid for by THL and cannot be withdrawn. Play at healthlottery + onlyTCs apply. BeGambleAware.org She then started to volunteer – and found her vocation, which led her to Pallion, where her nickname is Community Angel. Over the past month Karen has noticed more people than ever need help as fuel bills rise and the cost-of-living crisis bites. “The fuel hikes aren’t in line with people’s wages and benefits, so we’re helping as much as we can. But we don’t just want to stick a plaster over it. Do we need to get people into better-paid jobs  Do we need to upskill them ” she asks. “There are lots of reasons why people are struggling now. They might have lost their jobs or used up their savings during the Covid pandemic. Some people are on benefits – but we’ve got a lot of people who are working hard just to put food on the table.” The Pallion Action Group is just one of the projects that has received funding from Peopleaposs Health Trust with money raised through The Health Lottery, and every time you play you’re supporting local communities like these. More than £million has been given to over , projects, making a real dference to more than , people’s lives. Many good causes have been supported, including help for people with dementia, loneliness, learning dficulties and mental health issues thanks to the Health Lottery.“Without funding raised through The Health Lottery we’d be operating on a shoestring – and asking our staff to do things for nothing when they’re struggling as well,” says Karen. “I thinkyou’re buying a Health Lottery ticket, you’re winning anyway. Evenyou don’t win any money, you’re helping to fund projects in your local community. And you’re changing lives.”  £million won in prizes since   million prize winners – and counting! , winners every week Five main draws each week with a chance to win £k Second prize draw with a chance to win K every Wednesday and SaturdayPlay at healthlottery + onlyTCs apply. news uk-news adorable-dog-spends-four-years-"Adorable dog Patrick spent four years in kennels after rescueByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsDespite his loving personality, little Patrick has spent almost his entire le in shelter. The poor pooch was picked up by dog catchers at just one-year-old after being found wandering the streets in search of food. He was later saved by Barking Mad Dog Rescue, who have been trying to secure him a loving home since summer . The four-year-old dog has been described as a friendly lad who has been waiting four years for a family to want him.Hilary Anderson of Barking Mad Dog Rescue said: It is sad to see him waiting so long before he is someone’s dog again. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.  Patrick came from the public shelter to us in August . So really was still only a pup when the dog catchers had taken him. We think he was either someone’s pup who was then abandoned, or was looked after and handled by someone localhe had been born and lived on the street as he is so happy to see people and get some attention. Patrick gets on well with the other dogs in the rescue shelter so should be able to live with another dog in his new home. The crossbreed can be rehomed anywhere in the UK. Hilary, from Scotland, launched Barking Mad Dog Rescue after rescuing her dog Pixie following a Facebook appeal.She said: “Pixie lived in a park in Bucharest, with her mum, brother and six other dogs. “They were fed, vaccinated and neutered by a woman who wanted to help the park strays. “The pack survived the best way they could. Winters were harsh. Theirbuilt them a kennel and locals smashed it to pieces.” But their lives changed in  when new laws came in ordering strays to be rounded up and killed. “Pixie, like many others, found herself in a privately-owned shelter. Although safe from the dog catchers, Pixie had lost everything  - her freedom and her le. She stopped eating and couldn’t get used to le behind bars. ”In desperation, the woman who had cared for Pixie in the park posted her on Facebook asking for someone to take her away from Romania and give her the home she deserved.” Hilary answered this plea and ended up adopting Pixie alongside two other dogs, Elsa and Kirsty, before starting up her own rescue. The Barking Mad Dog Rescue team nowto Romania every two months to visit their own shelters in Constanta. If youaposre interested in rehoming Patrick, or any other dogs under Barking Mad Dog Rescueaposs care, submit an application through their website www.barkingmaddogrescue.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news best-place-live-uk-announced-"Phil Spencer reveals the best place to live in the UK in BySam Elliott-GibbsReporterVicky ShawLucy Thornton:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A tiny town in Yorkshire has been crowned Britainaposs best place to live, beating a host of big cities in the process.Ilkley near Bradford, west Yorkshire, has topped a list of  locations in the UK. Top class schools, a buzzing high street, the good rail links and breathtaking views, all landed the town with the top spot. Judges said they were impressed by the sports clubs available and the opportunities that they present for young people. The guide to the UK’s best towns includes  locations and is decided by Sunday Times’s judges. They decided the best place in London to live is Crystal Palace, in Kent it is Sevenoaks and The Chalke Valley in Wiltshire is top in the South East.  In the North West the best place was Trawden in Lancashire. Residents of Ilkley were thrilled with the fantastic accolade. John Oddy, , a partner at Ascentis accountants told The Mirror: “I joke by saying it’s a bit like Royston Vasey, you will never leave. “But seriously it’s a wonderful place you would not get me out of here with a stick of dynamite. “The first thing to say about Ilkley is it is in a beautul part of Yorkshire to start with, in God’s own country, with all the wonderful scenery and walks.” He said during the pandemic “as horrendous as it was we were blessed to live in Ilkley because of the number of fabulous walks available. “In just over half an hour you can be in the Yorkshire Dales and a little beyond that you can be in the Lake District.  “We are  minutes away from Leeds Bradford airport and it’s great for families. “The schools are fantastic. People move here just to get into the schools. There is also a really great community spirit. The town is clean, there is no crime, certainly no violent crime.” And as for the sport, he added: “There are three cricket clubs actually in the town, level five rugby club with over  members. Ilkley tennis club is fabulous, the golf club and much more. “It’s dficult to think of a typical British sport you can’t play here.” Born and bred in Ilkley, Richard Bradley, chairman of the ‘Friend’s of King’s Hall,’ an Edwardian theatre in the town centre opposite the station, said: “We have been in the top five on a number of occasions so it comes as no surprise. It’s a fantastic accolade. “I will never leave. Why would you want to leave somewhere that offers so much  “It’s a wonderful town to live in and ultimately I am not surprised because the town has so much to offer for the young and for old.  “It’s got a wide range of restaurants and pubs. It’s not a wild night out in Ilkley - it’s ultimately more of an eating-in and events town. The youngsters go and drink in Leeds. My son is  and he will find it very boring and goes off to Leeds to do all the clubbing.” Former Londoner Trevor Yong, , a sales boss, has lived in Yorkshire since  and moved to Ilkley, where his we project manager Lucy, , is from, four years later. “When I first moved I thought it was the exact opposite of London in a good way.” Now settled and chairman of Ilkley Round Table, he said: “The people of Ilkley are some of the most generous, I personally, have ever encountered. Because of their time and their donations.” He said yearly they raise almost £, with two key events a year, the beer festival in February and the Ilkley half marathon. And even in the pandemic their virtual marathon raised £, to fund a child heart monitor at Leeds General Infirmary. “I think the community is what Ilkley is all about,” he added.  The Places to Live  regional winners:East of England, Norwich, Norfolk London, Crystal Palace Midlands, Uppingham, Rutland Northern Ireland, Ballycastle, County Antrim North and North East, Slaithwaite, West Yorkshire North West, Trawden, Lancashire Scotland, Isle of Bute, Argyll South East, Sevenoaks, Kent South West, The Chalke Valley, Wiltshire Wales, Llandeilo, CarmarthenshireRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchoolsHousingMirror More Hopeful" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bt engineer sacked calling female
story: BT engineer sacked for calling female motorist silly cow in road rage dramaThe stunned woman made a complaint to Openreach about BT engineer Colin Aldreds behaviour and it turned out he had already been given a written warning over his road rage previously.Colin Aldred was driving his work BT Openreach van when he had a near missImage: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesByLiam Buckler:,  Apr |comments A BT engineer was sacked after calling a female motorist a silly cow and squaring up to her during a road rage incident, a tribunal heard.Colin Aldred, from the North West, was driving his work BT Openreach van when he had a near miss which resulted in him shouting a torrent of foul language at the woman. Mr Aldred then got out of his car and the woman said he squared up to me in quite an aggressive manner. The stunned woman made a complaint to Openreach about Aldredaposs behaviour and it turned out he had already been given a written warning by BT over his road rage previously. Mr Aldred, a customer service engineer, worked for Openreach from April  until April . As part of his job he attended yearly training about how to treat the public with respect.In a previous incident, he got out of his car at a KFC drive-thru and aggressively charged at an NHS doctor. He then went to verbally abuse the female driver and after being investigated he was later sacked and told his bosses to stick my job up your arse. However, after disagreeing with his sacking, Mr Aldred sued Openreach over his sacking, where a judge ruled there was absolutely no excuse in abusing the woman and that the engineer was lucky to keep his job for so long. Due to a fault in Openreachaposs sacking procedure, Mr Aldred won one claim of unfair dismissal on a technicality but he wasnapost awarded any compensation. The company is part of BT and is responsible for maintaining telephone lines which connect British homes and businesses to the national broadband and telephone network. Manchester Employment Tribunal heard complaints were made about Aldred in February  when an Openreach customer complained about him. In October , at Penketh telephone exchange, Cheshire, Aldred angrily swore at a staff member.A tribunal report said: Aldred told the tribunal that he was desperate for the toilet that day and had in fact soiled himself and in frustration had sworn at the member of staff. The [staff member], who had refused Aldred access, had done so because he had not provided the correct security pass. In October , there were concerns about Aldredaposs behaviour as was found to have been rude at a doctor. The report said: A member of the public who was a medical doctor in the NHS complained to Openreach about the behaviour of Aldred. He gave a detailed account explaining that Aldred was behind the doctor at the drive-through when he beeped the horn of his vehicle and shouted expletives including aposI havenapost got all fucking dayapos. When the doctor asked the claimant to stop, he alleged the claimant became more aggressive. The doctor got out of his vehicle to take a photograph of the number plate of Aldredaposs vehicle. He said Aldred then exited his vehicle and aggressively advanced toward the doctor shouting thathe had a problem, he should square up to him face to face. The doctor had a young child in the front seat of the vehicle who was becoming distressed. In that instance, Mr Aldred was suspended and given a written warning, admitting that he shouted I only have  minutes for lunch. And in December  he verbally abused the female driver, with the report saying: The member of the public alleged Aldred had been travelling at speed and almost aposripped off my doorapos. She admitted she had not seen the van coming around the corner. She put her hand up to apologise to the driver and was rewarded with a apostorrent of foul language being shouted at me through the windowapos. She then said that she walked around the corner to where the vehicle was parked, and a middle-aged man got out and began to apossquare up to me in quite an aggressive mannerapos. She admitted to swearing at him in response to his manner. The tribunal heard how Colin Aldred had reported the near miss but did not tell his boss about his offensive remark. He later admitted calling the woman a silly cow but denied confronting her. He was later sacked in April  but claimed it was unfair at tribunal. Employment Judge Katherine Ross said: Evenhe felt frustrated, Aldred should not have used offensive language in those circumstances. There is absolutely no excuse for it. We find Aldred was  per cent to blame. We have had regard to the evidence which shows that he had been involved in a series of incidents during the course of his employment where he had behaved offensively towards members of the public, another employee and his manager. A disinterested observer might consider that Aldred had been fortunate to keep his job for so long. Judge Ross said his dismissal was a reasonable response by Openreach. However, Aldredaposs claim of unfair dismissal succeeded as he was not given a recording of a witness statement before he was sacked. His compensation was reduced by  per cent as the judge ruled he would have been sacked evencorrect procedures were followed. Mr Aldred also brought claims of disability discrimination and harassment against his employer, alleging that he was discriminated against on grounds of his stress and anxiety. However, his claims were thrown out. title: kind caring boxer 22 who
story: Kind and caring boxer, , who lost leg to cancer dies weeks after getting marriedKeen sportsman Bailey Lindsay, who had his leg amputated after first being diagnosed with cancer when he was a teenager, died just two months after getting marriedBailey Lindsays death has left new we Isabel devastated Image: Lindsay familyByJasmine NordenSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Apr |comments A much-loved young boxer died after battling a rare form of bone cancer just weeks after marrying the love of his le. Bailey Lindsay, , lost his fight against the disease on Wednesday, the newlywedaposs devastated we Isabel announced. His widow Isabel posted a heartfelt tribute to him on Facebook yesterday.The amputee sportsman from Doncaster, Yorkshire, refused to let his diagnosis stop him enjoying his le and they said aposI doapos in February.Bailey, who was also a model, appeared on TV singing competition aposI Can See Your Voiceapos, YorkshireLive reports.Friends and family posted emotional tributes to him as they mourned his passing.Keir Nicholson, who was a close friend of Bailey, said: Bailey was the most beautul, kind, and caring young man you could ever meet but Baileyaposs journey in le was not mapped out to be the easiest. All we could do as friends was to make this journey as fun and memorable as possible for our dear friend. Some of us had only know Bailey a short amount of time but the impact and impression he left on our souls and lives is monumental. Bailey would first come into my le after I had lost my own mother to bone cancer. Bailey’s story resonated with me immediately and I wanted to do all I could for this young man as a friend.  He went to his first AmpCamp in June . AmpCamp was founded by Ben Lovell, a mutual friend of Keiraposs, and works with both adult and child amputees to support and rehabilitate them. We would both go on to feel he was like the little brother we always wanted to protect, Keir added. Bailey inspired everyone he met on these camps with his dedication to staying fit and motivated, his passion to make sure future bone cancer patients would be better supported and of course, that beautul smile of Bailey’s was enough to inspire and charm anyone. I think many of us had a man crush on our boy Bailey. Bailey joined the AmpCamp mountain climbers and set himself the challenge of climbing Ben Nevis to raise money for kids with limb dferences. Keir praised his endurance, bravery, strength and courage. Bailey also worked with children who attended AmpCamp. Bailey enjoyed boxing, and had once carried Josh Warringtonaposs belt into a game, and even sparred with Tyson Fury. He was also a big fan of Leeds United. Josh Warrington posted a tribute to Bailey yesterday.Sadly, Bailey found out his cancer had ed around Christmas . He and Isabel were able to get married in February, but had less than two months of marriage before he died on April . Keir said: He was a devoted big brother and a beautul boy to his parents. In Bailey’s passing he leaves a wonderful set of family and friends as well as a beautul and devoted we in Isabel Lindsay. A we and friend we are all so proud of for giving the care, devotion and love to in Baileys le and in those final months. We will all do what we can to honour Bailey’s memory. Bailey, you are loved Bailey, you are missed Bailey, you are never forgotten. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Baileyaposs we Isabel also posted a heartfelt tribute to him on Facebook yesterday. She wrote: My gorgeous perfect Husband gained his angel wings in the early hours of this morning, holding my hand and surrounded by his family. I feel I have so much to say about Bailey but right now I am struggling to find the words. Bailey changed my le and in many ways he saved me. He has taught me so much about how to live le the right way, pushing yourself to make the most of every moment, every opportunity, and every challenge too. Isabel added: Bailey will be in all of our hearts for the rest of our lives and I just know that even though he is no longer with us in person, he isn’t finished with making an impact yet, and I will continue to do that for Bailey. AmpCamp founder Ben and amputee Paul Ellis will be climbing Ben Nevis at Easter to raise money for the kids with limb dferences who attend the camps, but also in Baileyaposs memory.You can donate to the fundraiser here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tyson FuryLoveTeenagersClimbingCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get all the boxing  MMA updates you need with our Mirror Fighting email update - sign up hereInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man unable bath shower two
story: Man unable to have a bath or shower for TWO YEARS due to council delaysThe father of two approached Southampton City Council back in  to install a shower in the bathroom due to his health issues, but no work has been undertakenRetired milkman Michael Davey says he hasnt had a bath or shower for two years due to council delays in installing a shower in his flat. Image: Daily Echo Solent NewsByLiam Buckler:,  Apr |commentsA retired milkman claims he has been unable to shower or bath for two years due to council delays in installing a shower in his flat.Michael Davey, , from Southampton, struggles to get upstairs due to his arthritis and other health issues. He can no longer use the bath and instead relies on bed baths given to him by his we Stella.The father of two approached Southampton City Council back in  to install a shower in the bathroom due to his health issues, but no work has been undertaken. He said: I was told Iaposd have to move to another property before any internal adaptations would take place, but none of the homes I viewed online was suitable for a disabled person. I havenapost had a shower or bath in two years. I feel Iaposve been ignored by the council.In order to fund improvements, people applying for a means-tested Disabled Facilities Grant must have their needs assessed by an occupational therapist. And Southampton is one of ten council areas in England and Wales where disabled people wait on average more than a year before they can submit an application, according to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism . Once applicants apply, they can then wait a further  months for the work to be started, which for Michael is a long time to wait. Fazilet Hadi, of Disability Rights UK, said disabled people often found it dficult to complete simple everyday actions that others took for granted. Itaposs critical that councils keep this at the front of their minds when telling disabled people there is a wait of months for adaptations. A Southampton City Council spokesperson today cited the high demand for alterations to properties. Long waits can often be due to special or complex situations but we aim to deal with critical cases within four weeks. The councilworking very hard and pushing to reduce waiting times where possible. aposaposThe pandemic has added additional pressures with increased staff absences and home visits restricted so we could protect the people we work with, causing delays to assessments, approvals and completion of works. Southampton City council declined to disclose how many people are on the waiting list but said the list is easing. In order for properties occupied by people with mobility issues, they are often funded by a Disabled Facilities Grant. In  a report published to say the means-tested grants had helped more than , people a year to live in more accessible housing since its inception in . However, there is a long wait before someone disabled can apply for funding as their needs must be assessed by an occupational therapist, with thousands of disabled people across the UK are waiting months to be assessed - and waiting possibly years to have the work completed.A Southampton City Council spokesperson said: Disabled Facilities Grant cases are often complex and the time taken from initial application to approval and subsequent completion will y considerably depending on the scale of the works and the needs of the inidual. Additional resources are being recruited across the teams and a large-scale service review is underway to identy improvements to service delivery. This has lead to campaigners calling for an increase in the number of purpose-built houses to be built for the disabled, as applicants can be forced to wait years. The Disability charity Leonard Cheshire says people in two thirds of English council areas wait longer than a year, with a quarter of council areas waiting more than two years. A spokesperson for the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities, said, We recognise the importance of improving accessibility, and the number of accessible homes has nearly doubled in a decade. Councils are best placed to decide how much accessible housing is needed in their area and they should reflect this in their plans for future development.
