title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineJust  weeks’ notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region’s elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country – have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor’s owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care – but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don’t have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure – with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke – but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete – andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual’s home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220406newschinese named northern ireland s most popular takeaway
story: The decision-making process of ordering a takeaway often ides opinion, with debates sparking almost every day as households fail to come to an agreement on which delicious treat they should indulge in. But is your preferred cuisine dependent on where you live  Wanting to settle the age-old debate, Just-Eat have conducted a sentiment analysis of over  million restaurant reviews across the UK. Each gastronomy was awarded a popularity score out of  based on the positive sentiments surrounding each food genre, ultimately uncovering the most popular cuisine across the UK. Just-Eat can reveal that Chinese cuisine is the most popular across Northern Ireland. The classic dishes that rank as the country’s favourites include sweet and sourand chow mein . Close in popularity is Japanese cuisine, which gains second place with its score of .. Here, tofu dishesare slightly more popular than sushi . Italian is once again a popular choice, and for Northern Ireland it’s the peoples’ third favourite cuisine, scoring . out of . The highest rated Italian dish is ravioli , closely followed by lasagnaand macaroni and cheese . Attaining a positive rank in the top five for the first time, British fare is Northern Ireland’s fourth favourite cuisine, claiming . popularity points. Black pudding is the number one British dish in Northern Ireland, scoring an impressive . out of . The Yorkshire pudding is the second favouriteand the classic BLT sandwich is the third most popular choicein Northern Ireland. Rounding off Northern Ireland’s top five favourite cuisines is Indian with a popularity rating of . out of . Creamy butter chicken is the first choice dish , with kormaand chicken tikkaclose in rankings.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newsthe people you are visiting may be particularly vulnerable
story: The public has been urged to keep wearing face coverings when visiting hospitals, care homes and other health and care settings. The appeal from the Chief Medical Officer comes with reports of a decline in wearing of face coverings by visitors. Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “The COVID- Omicron iant is extremely infectious and, despite best efforts, can spread quickly in health and social care settings. “Please remember to wear a face covering when you are visiting. The people you are coming to see may be particularly vulnerable to the virus - as may other patients or residents. “Also, do not visityou have symptoms of respiratory infection.” The Chief Medical Officer added: “Wearing a face covering remains an important way to protect others, as well as yourself. Public health advice continues to encourage their use in everyday le. That also includes on public transport and in any indoor busy setting - especiallythey are not well ventilated.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newstranslink bus drivers to go on strike later this month
story: Unite has confirmed initial dates for strike action on Ulsterbus andbus services. These will be taken in conjunction with GMB who also represents bus workers at Translink. The strike action planned will be a week, starting April  and concluding on May , as well as a single day on Friday, May . The strike comes after members of the union overwhelmingly voted for industrial action after rejecting the latest Translink management pay offer. Unite general secretary Sharon Graham expressed her support for the striking bus workers. She said, “These bus workers are frontline workers – they deserve respect and a pay increase. Translink needs to grasp that there’s a cost of living crisis destroying the value of wages andwith a more acceptable offer. “Unite’s members have my full support and that of their union in taking this strike action for fairer pay.” Unite deputy Regional Secretary Davy Thompson is lead officer for Translink, Northern Ireland’s bus and rail public transport provider. He added:“Unite represents the overwhelming majority of bus workers, and this strike action taken in conjunction with GMB which also represents bus workers will shut down all bus services. “Bus workers deserve a pay increase. The ball is in the court of Translink management. They can to avoid this unnecessary and highly disruptive strike – they need to address our members’ legitimate pay expectations.” Meanwhile, Peter Macklin, GMB Organiser, said:Every worker deserves fair pay. With rampant inflation, this real terms cut is a slap in the face and will leave many struggling to cover their bills. “Translinkfails to recognise what workers went through during the pandemic. “They kept transport running so other essential workers could get to and from workplaces to perform vital roles. “Our members were proud to carry out their duty in delivering the service, potentially putting themselves and their families at risk. When we clapped every Thursday night, we said the essential workers would not be forgotten or left behind. But during this cost of living crisis, Translink is forgetting their own workers. “The dispute, which affects bus drivers, cleaners and shunters will close the entire bus network within Northern Ireland. It will be a complete shutdown.” A Translink spokesperson said they were disappointed that the unions hadvoted to take industrial action. “Following extensive negotiations, including with the Labour Relations Agency, we made a pay offer of % plus an enhanced package of conditions that included a % increase in weekend and overtime rates along with  extra days holiday, they said. “We believe this was a fair and reasonable offer and have at all times been open to discussions. We remain committed to working with the unions to avert this action. “We would welcome the opportunity to engage with unions to cover school duties, so that the wellbeing of schoolchildren can remain a priority. “All train services will continue to operate as normal. “We will communicate relevant passenger information through the media, on our website www.translink, through social media, in stations and on buses and trains. “Translink apologises for any inconvenience this may cause”.

title: ballycastle is northern irelands best place to live in 2022 proud locals are in full agreement as co antrim town edges out derry and
story: Seafront: Ballycastle has been named Northern Ireland#s best place to live in the annual Sunday Times list.The mile-long beach at Ballycastle was described as beautulMarie Fox with baby EvaFinn DelaneyClaire Byrne FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSeafront: Ballycastle has been named Northern Ireland#s best place to live in the annual Sunday Times list.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFor the people of Ballycastle, it seems an obvious choice their home town has been picked as the best place to live in Northern Ireland.As they pass by its picturesque harbour, families and business owners in the Co Antrim town talk fondly of the epic coastal views on their doorstep.Rathlin Island is a short ferry trip away and Scotland is also visible on a clear day.Although a small seaside town, Ballycastle boasts a thriving Main Street with multiple cafes, greengrocers and fish and chip shops.Picked as part of the annual Sunday Times Best Places to Live, Ballycastle was chosen ahead of Londonderry and Helen’s Bay.Read MoreGarrett Hargan:OpinionDerry one of best places to live in Northern Ireland: A rich history, friendly people, and proud music and sporting traditions make city a fantastic place to liveDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read More‘There’s no place like home’: Derry Girls writer Lisa McGee reacts to city being named among top places to live in NIRead MoreBest places to live in the UK revealed They said of Ballycastle: “This unspoilt fishing village is a real coastal town rather than a tourist honeypot, with a strong independent streak and a welcoming atmosphere.“There’s a vibrant food scene, with everything from old-fashioned fish and chips at Morton’s by the harbour to tasty sourdough at Ursa Minor bakery.“The mile-long beach and beautul surroundings make it a blissful base for families.”With an average house price of £,, Ballycastle has experienced growth of % since .Enjoying time at the play park with two of her children, lelong resident Marie Foxagreed it was an ideal spot for families.“It’s definitely good for young ones. Great schools and it’s brilliant for walks on the beach,” she said.“It does get a lot busier here in the summer as well whenever we get the markets.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseMarie Fox with baby Eva FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMarie Fox with baby EvaPrimary school teacher Claire Byrne said: “We go for a walk every single day and it’s lovely just to get out.“My children have grown up here and went to secondary school and they have loved it.” Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseClaire Byrne FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueClaire ByrneAt family-run Shorebird Coffee Hut, James Delaneyand son Finnagreed their home town was a worthy winner.“It’s not a big surprise, really. I have five kids and they all play sports and last night we had a party for an aunt out in one of the local restaurants,” said James.“In Portrush you will get a lot more things like arcades, but people like that Ballycastle is unspoiled in that way.”He said one downside was the lack of a leisure centre with a swimming pool, meaning locals had to travel to Ballymoney or Coleraine.Finn added: “I do think it is a nice place to live, it’s a good mix of tourists and local people. So you know all the faces and there’s plenty of places to walk.“Looking out the window you can see Scotland on a clear day.” Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFinn Delaney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFinn DelaneyAskedhe ever feels cut off from areas like Belfast, he said: “To be honest, there’s plenty of stuff to do here.“You get lots of people from surrounding towns coming down here, even though it’s not a massive community, people come down for all the bars and nightclubs.”Dympna McNallylives in London still visits Ballycastle, where her parents grew up, once a month.“I can only speak personally, but I do think it’s quite friendly. I like the fact it’s not too busy, the scenery is beautul, the shops are good. What more could you ask for ” she said.“A downside is that it’s not very well connected with transport links. It’s a shame the train doesn’t come here anymore.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDympna McNally from London visits Ballycastle every month. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDympna McNally from London visits Ballycastle every month.Ulster Unionist councillor Joan Baird spent her school years in the town. She said it became a refuge for her during the Troubles when she visited her parents at the weekend.“The community here, by and large, has got on very well together over the years and still does,” she said.“This is going to be demonstrated now when we get our shared campus between the senior schools in the town.“All of that adds up to a very good community. People are very friendly and it is a lovely place to live, with the beautul environment we have with the Glens of Antrim.“Of course, you have the sea and Rathlin Island so close by.“It’s a fabulous place to live, but it’s very important that we keep it that way.“It’s not just going to always happen. You have to strive to make sure that ethos of community spirit and togetherness survives into the future.”Sinn Fein councillor Cara McShane said it was “fantastic news” for Ballycastle.“It’s a privilege to live and work here,” she said.“We are never complacent about this part of the world — there’s stunning views of Rathlin Island, Mull of Kintyre, Fair Head clf, which is nestled in the shadow of Knockglade Mountain.”She added a major selling point was a strong, independent retail offering, as well as a high number of producers in the local artisan food market.While frustrated at times that local government spending can be “Coleraine and Portrush-centric”, she is hopeful of plans currently out for consultation for a new greenway linking Ballymoney and Ballycastle.“That will offer people coming from places like Belfast the chance to get the train as far as Ballymoney, and of course you could then cycle, walk or run to Ballycastle,” she said.“That is exciting. We know we live in a unique area.“But we’re always progressive and thinking of other ways to let other people come to Ballycastle.”Related topicsUlster Unionist PartySinn FéinMore On Ulster Unionist Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumDerry one of best places to live in Northern Ireland: A rich history, friendly people, and proud music and sporting traditions make city a fantastic place to liveGarrett HarganExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDerry City Walls FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDerry City WallsApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDerry has rightly been recognised as one of the best places to live in Northern Ireland given the city’s welcoming atmosphere and history.The Sunday Times took account of a wide range of factors — from schools, transport and broadband to culture, green spaces and the health of the high street.The Best Places to Live list celebrates improving towns, villages or city centres, attractive, well-designed homes and locations bursting with community spirit.What makes Derry a great place to live is its rich history and people who are both warm and friendly with a sense of comradery.That is not conjecture or bias from a local, but is borne out in polls where the city sits at the top for being the most generous in the UK for donations on pages such as GoFundMe.The city is believed to have been founded by Saint Columba in AD . That means there is much for visitors to explore, from ancient to modern history.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreBallycastle is Northern Ireland’s best place to live in : Proud locals are in full agreement as Co Antrim town edges out Derry and Helen’s Bay‘There’s no place like home’: Derry Girls writer Lisa McGee reacts to city being named among top places to live in NIYou have the completely intact -year-old Derry Walls which is a real selling point for tourists.Other historic landmarks include the Guildhall — where it now stands was once the middle of the River Foyle where ships moored. It was mostly destroyed by fire in  and after extensive rebuilding was opened in .Because it is relatively small in size, Derry is an easy place to navigate for visitors.A key piece of infrastructure built in recent times was the Peace Bridge.Nowadays it is hard to imagine the city without it, and it’s an area of recreation popular with walkers and joggers.That area is arguably the best feature of the city, expanding the city centre, linking to Ebrington, St Columb’s Park and the renovated railway station.The Peace Bridge connects the Cityside and Waterside it was a masterstroke both in practical terms and as an act of symbolism by reconnecting the largely Catholic Cityside to the traditionally unionist Waterside. Derry is also a city of culture — made official in  — with musicians, poets, painters and actors famous the world over.Danny Boy is one of the most famous songs in the world, and has been covered by Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash and Eva Cassidy. Phil Coulter, The Undertones, Dana, Cara Dillon, Johnny McDaid of Snow Patrol fame, Red Organ Serpent Sound, Fighting with Wire, SOAK and Wood Burning Savages show the range of musicians Derry has produced.It is also a city with proud sporting traditions in GAA and football and has produced Olympic medallists and world champions who first learned their trade on Derry’s pitches, roads and rivers.Nowhere does a festival like Derry, but there should be more added to the calendar.You have Glasgowbury in Draperstown, the City of Derry Jazz and Big Band Festival, the legendary Halloween festival and, in recent times, the Foyle Maritime Festival, which have all proven popular.When considering Derry, you also have to factor in the location. A short drive across the border and you’re in some of the world’s nicest beaches including Dunree and Tullagh Bay.To Derry’s advantage in the Sunday Times survey was an average house price of £,.“Reaping the rewards of years of investment and with a fine cultural reputation, this much-improved city stands out as somewhere cool, credible and cheap, with a bright future,” The Sunday Times states.But most people in the city would disagree with that statement, as multiple-deprivation measures, unemployment rates and analysis of investment show the second city has not received a great deal of inward investment.For example, since Invest NI was formed in  until   it has assisted , new jobs in Belfast whereas Foyle got , and East Londonderry ,.In that time it invested £.bn in Belfast and £.bn between Foyle and East Londonderry.Most ReadArlene Foster accuses Naomi Long and Alliance Party of being ‘nasty’ when ‘mask slips’ in Twitter spatStormont department apologises and drops its title: regeneration plan to be developed for frightening shaftesbury square in belfast
story: Belfast#s Shaftesbury Square. Picture: Google Maps FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBelfast#s Shaftesbury Square. Picture: Google MapsMichael Kenwood, Local Democracy reporterApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast council has vowed to work on a “tactical regeneration” plan for the rundown Shaftesbury Square area in the city centre.The area used to be the crowning glory of Belfast’s so-called “golden mile” – which stretched from Lisburn Road along the fullof Great Victoria Street – but in recent decades has seen steady decline and is noted for its empty premises and dilapidated facades.This week during a meeting of the City Growth and Regeneration Committee at Belfast City Council, elected representatives agreed a proposal from council officers to create a plan for the area to be shared with the relevant Stormont departments, businesses and other stakeholders. The “tactical regeneration” scheme will also look at enhancement of the Castle Street area.It involves quick short term and low cost actions such as transforming dingy former shopfronts, opening up public realm space by taking away street clutter such as bollards, opening up fenced off areas, introducing artworks, parklets and greening.A committee report states: “Whilst certain businesses have sustained a presence in the area and continue to make a positive contribution in terms of well-maintained active frontages, there are a number of vacancies and the wider area is in need of signicant intervention.“It should be noted that there are several development proposals progressing through the planning process in the wider area, and major public sector placemaking and infrastructure projects like Belfast Streets Ahead  and BRT  also have the potential to have a transformative impact.“However, the timescales associated with emerging or committed public and private projects in this area are y, and in some cases uncertain, and there is a growing consensus among local stakeholders that there is a need for shorter term action.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up It adds: “Officers are proposing that a tactical regeneration scheme is worked up for part of this area initially. Whilst the detail needs to be developed, it could include a combination of minor works to building frontages, while also taking advantage of generous footway widths along Great Victoria Street through measures such as removal of street clutter and introduction of soft landscaping and greening opportunities, where possible.“It is proposed that a scheme be developed that focuses on Great Victoria Street, east and west sides, from Bruce St to Donegall Rd, as a priority given the condition of this area.”The council says that the Stormont Department for Communities has indicated that funding may be available in the   financial period,projects can be developed up to a “business case” status.Further funding may come from the South West Quarter Stakeholders Group, a group comprising a mix of private sector business council officers, Translink, NIHE and two Stormont departments.DUP Botanic Councillor Tracy Kelly said: “If you look at Great Victoria Street and the mouth of the city centre, it’s absolutely horrendous. It needs a massive piece of work and investment. So I am so glad to see some thought going into it.“There are a few shops going on to the Donegall Road, just off Shaftesbury Square that recently got funding from the council to give them a bit of a le with shop front work and a bit of paint, and that has made a massive dference already.”She added: “When you think of the golden mile, and what it used to be – it is quite frightening now at night time around there.”Green Councillor Mal O’Hara said: “Parts of the inner fringe around the city core have been ruined by the car dependency of this city and the need to ensure we have traffic flow. Sandy Row, a once vibrant and bustling shopping district, has been ruined to become a cut-through for traffic flow.” He asked for space to be taken away from private cars as part of the regeneration projects.In , a £ million Belfast Transport Hub was approved by the council, involving the creation of a new bus and train centre on the other side of Durham Street to the current Great Victoria Street bus and train stations Those stations will be replaced with a mall.The wider Weaver’s Cross plan involves the regeneration of land to the immediate south of the current train and bus centre, land currently used as parking space on either side of Hope Street and Bruce Street, cutting through Great Victoria Street. A public space is planned beside the new transport hub called “Saltwater Square.”Most ReadStormont department apologises and drops its legal challenge over whistleblowerArlene Foster accuses Naomi title: alliance assembly candidate connie egan jokes that vandals of her election posters are terrible at art
story: Connie Egan and Andrew Muir had their photographs defaced on election posters throughout parts of Bangor this week. Credit: Connie Egan TwitterUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paint FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueConnie Egan and Andrew Muir had their photographs defaced on election posters throughout parts of Bangor this week. Credit: Connie Egan TwitterNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAlliance councillor Connie Egan has poked fun at the vandalism of her election poster in parts of Bangor, joking that it’s a “terrible” show of “artwork”.The North Down Assembly candidate shared photos of the ruined posters, which show pictures of both Ms Egan and her colleague Andrew Muir. Their faces have been completely scored out by black and red colourings, to which Ms Egan wrote: “Disappointed to see the terrible artwork on display in parts of Bangor. North Down is an area full of local talent, I know you can do better than this!”Many online users shared their support for the Bangor West councillor, with one writing: “See it as a positive, you are rattling someone#s cage.”Another joked: “Your picture isn#t that bad, solid  for effort, the lines bring it to a solid  though.”Disappointed to see the terrible artwork on display in parts of Bangor. North Down is an area full of local talent, I know you can do better than this! pic UYMRVVdyT— Connie EganApril , Last summer, Ms Egan made headlines by repurposing her old council election posters to Ulster Wildle, who transformed them into footprint tunnels for the local hedgehog population.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The tunnels are used in the ongoing Irish Hedgehog Survey, which aims to help researchers gain full knowledge of the ious habitats of hedgehogs here and across the island of Ireland.Another Assembly candidate who hasn’t been taking graffiti artists too seriously is the Ulster Unionist Party#s candidate for North Belfast, former PUP councillor Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston. On Tuesday, she managed to turn the tables when a poster of hers was defaced with blue paint. In response, Ms Corr-Johnston posted a picture of her face on social media covered in blue paint with the caption: Today#s look is inspired by anonymous.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paint FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUUP#s Julie-Anne Corr-Johnston reacts to her poster being defaced with blue paintSince parties have began their latest campaigns for the upcoming  Assembly election, the PSNI have received numerous reports of theft and damage of election material across Northern Ireland.Nearly a fortnight ago, the TUV’s West Tyrone candidate Trevor Clarke said posters belonging to him, which were on display close to Edwards Primary School in Castlederg, were stolen.Mr Clarke said the “unlawful interference” would not deter his campaign and also challenged others “across the political spectrum” to condemn the incident.The SDLP’s Charlotte Carson recently had her poster set on fire at Cyprus Avenue in east Belfast too, and her colleague, Strangford candidate Conor Houston also had more than  posters stolen in the Newtownards area near the end of last month.Meanwhile, Sinn Fein MLA Jemma Dolan confirmed a number of her election posters in Enniskillen had been stolen and set alight.The Fermanagh and south Tyrone MLA wrote on social media: “Election posters are part of our democratic culture. Removing them is doing nothing but attempting to interfere with democracy.”Read MoreTUV hit out at ‘juvenile attack on democracy’ as election posters stolen in Co TyroneRelated topicsAlliance title: arlene foster accuses naomi long and alliance party of being nasty when mask slips in twitter spat
story: Arlene Foster and Naomi Long during the UTV Election Debate . Photo by William Cherry Press Eye. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArlene Foster and Naomi Long during the UTV Election Debate . Photo by William Cherry Press Eye.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFormer First Minister Arlene Foster has referred to the Alliance Party and its leader as “nasty” during an online spat with Naomi Long on Thursday morning.The Twitter argument began on Wednesday night, after the ex-DUP leader referred to an article in which Ms Long commented: “If the DUP doesn’t want to play ball, the government needs to change the rules.”Ms Foster re-shared the article, along with comments made by another Twitter user, which said: “Three years of Sinn Fein throwing its Teddy out of the pram for whatever, and no recollection of Alliance wanting the rules changed to address a lack of Executive’.Alongside these remarks, Ms Foster wrote: ‘Very true’. She was referring to the the three-year collapse of Stormont, which came about in January  when Sinn Fein said it would not go back into an Executivewith the DUP, unless legislation for an Irish language act was implemented, following the DUP and Ms Foster’s handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreAndrew Madden:OpinionElection briefing: From Arlene vs Naomi and election poster fights to the prettiest street in FoyleArlene Foster says ‘all to play for’ in Assembly election even with Sinn Fein ahead in ‘most of the polls’East Belfast Assembly candidate Ms Long replied: “No, it isn#t true, Arlene. We have consistently called for reform of the institutions to allow an Executive to be formed by those willing to do it. The DUP weren’t up for serious reform in that three years because your vetoes are mutual -Sinn Fein lost theirs, you#d lose yours.”Ms Foster, who is now a contributor to GB News, then claimed that “not once” did Ms Long say the government “should change the Belfast agreement to facilitate those of us who were willing to go into Stormont for three years whilst Sinn Fein kept us all out”.The Alliance leader said that she and her colleagues have reiterated “that *no* single party should be able to collapse the institutions” and that they “said it during the last suspension too”.And maybe you let us see how nasty you really are from time to time. #maskslips. #playtheball #nastyparty #alliance. https:t.co gGDMOUyOk— Arlene Foster #ProudofNI.April , She added that both the DUP and Sinn Fein “had red lines holding us all back” and said: “We raised reform throughout the talks, including voluntary coalitionand ending abuse of the petition of concern. Maybe you just weren#t over every jot and tittle To this, Ms Foster responded: “And maybe you let us see how nasty you really are from time to time. #maskslips. #playtheball #nastyparty #alliance.”Ms Long has since criticised the Fermanagh native’s remarks, telling her to “do better”, especially as she is a public campaigner against online bullying, to which Ms Foster stated that Ms Long should “do better yourself Naomi - try practising what you preach”.Related topicsArlene FosterNaomi LongAlliance PartyDemocratic Unionist PartyMore On Arlene FosterArlene Foster says ‘all to play for’ in title: independent candidate claire sugden using her artistic flair for election material
story: One of Claire Sugden’s posters. Credit: Claire Sugden FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueOne of Claire Sugden’s posters. Credit: Claire SugdenNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAssembly candidate Claire Sugden has revealed how she has been working into the wee small hours creating her own election posters, leaflets and social media imagery.Despite having no formal graphics training, the former East Londonderry MLA designs and writes all of her own election material — something she has been doing since she first stood for Stormont six years ago.“It saves me a considerable amount of money and it’s something I enjoy,” explained the independent unionist and former justice minister. “Whenever I was at the age when I was deciding what it was I wanted to do with my le, it was either politics or art. I ended up going down the political route, so it’s kind of nice that when it comes to election times, I can exercise that other side of things.“I have an A-level in art and that’s it. It’s all self-taught. My husband is a computer games artist, so I take a lot of advice from him, but a lot of it is Googling how to do things and, I think, having a bit of an eye for design anyway. None of it is perfect, I’m sure someone who is qualied and experienced in this field would be able to pull up something quicker and a lot more eye-catching, but I’m pleased with the way it turns out.”The Coleraine woman said she spent a few days last week “going round the constituency getting some photographs just to get nice fresh images for the literature”, but overall she’s kept to the same colour scheme and theme for her election content since she first stood in .“It can take a while, but sitting down I can get into a bit of a zone with it. You can find me maybe starting it at pm and still sitting until am in the morning because I’m on a bit of a roll with it. There’s other days when I get a bit of a block and that’s usually the days where you’re under pressure and trying to make deadlines for printers.”She joked: “If the election doesn’t go my way, maybe I have another career!”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumIt’s time to send election posters to the scrapheapEimear McGovernThere is no need for them and they’re not good for environmentExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseScrap: with social media and ious outlets there is no need for election posters. Credit: Graham Baalham-Curry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueScrap: with social media and ious outlets there is no need for election posters. Credit: Graham Baalham-CurryApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailYou can’t drink your morning coffee without an audience and as you walk down the road you are watched from all angles, both geometrically and politically.That’s right — election season is upon us and as a result, the faces of your local politicians on poster after poster are becoming more familiar than the heartthrobs we had on our walls as teenagers.It is one staple of election campaigns that has been around for decades,not centuries, and while there’s some sport initially in comparing the tenets of graphic design, colour schemes and haircutsof our political representatives, when you sit and think about it, is this something that’s really needed in this day and age As a journalist, I’m probablymore familiar with Northern Ireland’s politicians than the average person, given my job involves thinking, talking and writing about them on a daily basis. As such, I don’t often need a reminder of who there is to vote for in my constituency or what parties they stand for. I’ll admit that an election poster is certainly an easy way to raise awareness of, on a basic level, exactly who represents or wants to represent you.But after seeing the same person staring at me five times before I had crossed a single bridge in Coleraine where I live the other day, I started to wonder do posters influence how people vote — or are posters just a habit, one which may not serve the most purpose but indicates you have a dog in the fight Read MoreIndependent candidate Claire Sugden using her artistic flair for election materialThe ironic thing is that maybe posters mean much more to the smaller parties and independents with comparably smaller budgets to the more prominent frontrunners. For them, it’s more of a stretch to measure up the level of postering and the legwork it takes displayed by other parties but who worry they won’t get as much attentionthey don’t appear to have parity in terms of faces on streets.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Often described as CorriBoard posters, many of those massive signs you see on our streets and roads are made from one of the dirtiest words of our time — plastic. While the materials can sometimes be upcycled, it is suggested they will take hundreds of years to degrade, long after the politicians whose faces on which they featured and possibly even the parties they represented have departed this fine earth.It’s true that they do have benefits. They are immune to hackers which have plagued recent international elections . Not everyone has top class internet access so it does keep demographics informed. There’s no question that they send a message to voters and a reminder that an election is taking place — andyour local MLA hasn’t fixed that pothole on your road, you will know just the face to ask when they come a-canvassing.Green Party NI politician Mal O’Hara has joined some of his international colleagues in favouring a system seen in Europe where paper posters are erected in certain spaces only, instead of being festooned on every available surface. But this approach isn’t favoured by some larger parties who are able to spread their resources more widely and want to be able to show that. And so, without any wider consensus, the great poster parade marches on even in  when the word on all of our lips is the environment and many of us are kept awake at night wondering what sort of a world it is we’re leaving behind for the next generation and the one after that.What is the alternative  Some may argue it’s already here, and it’s called social media, where most views are shared and heard and your popularity isn’t always just down to what party backs you, but how well you use your voice. There’s also mainstream media via the television, news sites and newspapers as well as the radio. And for those who have access to neither, there’s canvassing — and feel free to reject those shiny leaflets which usually take a short trip to the bin in favour of a chat instead.Or why not make use of the screens in Belfast city centre or in shopping centres to instead display candidates posters on a revolving basis, on the proviso that these screens and devices would have to be made more widely available in our towns and villages Some may disregard these suggestions but surely there must be another way, instead of risking damage to the environment and obscuring our beautul landscape on this island with these massive posters cropping up at regular intervals.Whatever your thoughts on posters, the discourse around them doesn’t end after the election unfortunately. And while you might find the face of a local politician peaking out from behind a hedge or unlucky enough to be placed atop a bonfire, you will also be treated to the crowdsourcing operation that is your local politician asking you to make them aware of any forlorn final poster still lingering on our streets. Or at the very least, a photo of them with clippers in hand, telling all they are out and about removing their posters, sent to the rubbish heap, after election season comes to an end.Related title: northern ireland assembly election 2022 people have a choice to attend polling station if covid positive electoral
story: Northern Ireland will soon go to the polls. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNorthern Ireland will soon go to the polls. Credit: Liam McBurneyChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPeople who wake up on the day of the Assembly Election in May and test positive for Covid- or have symptoms “may still go to vote”, according to the Electoral Office.Virginia McVea, from the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland told BBC’s Good Morning Ulster show that the rules around the issue had been directed by the government.The chief electoral officer also confirmed there has been no change in the rules around postal and proxy voting to make allowances for Covid- and stressed that anyone who is vulnerable or has been shielding throughout the pandemic should apply by the deadline of April .When asked what people should dothey wake up on May  with symptoms or having tested positive for Covid, Ms McVea said “government has directed that you have a choice”.You can go to the polling station we are asking you to take every precaution,” she told BBC Radio Ulster.For others going into the polling station you will see all of the normal precautions that have come in everywhere  - perspex, automatic hand sanitisers, ventilation.You don’t lose your vote because what government has directed is that people who test positive or who have symptoms may still go to vote.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreWhen is the Northern Ireland Assembly Election   The key dates and all you need to know about how to voteThat is as the legislation sits. I am dutybound to communicate that to people, people will have dferent views on that, but that is what the government has directed. That is your choice.”Polling day at the forthcoming Assembly Election begins from am on Thursday May , with polling stations remaining open until pm that evening.When askedpeople can apply for a postal or proxy vote ahead of time in the event they do have Covid-, Ms McVea confirmed this was not possible.Anyone is free to apply [for a postal vote] but what must happen is it can’t be an entirely hypothetical situation. If someone has been shielding or there are mental health issue or other vulnerabilities, it would be reasonable at this point to say ‘I couldn’t expose myself to risk’,” she added.Government has directed that in Northern Ireland the normal absent vote legislation should apply, so there has been no change in Northern Ireland to make allowance for Covid and that means April  is such an important deadline for anyone who has been shielding or who is frail or vulnerable.”The Department of Health has been approached for comment.Most ReadArlene Foster accuses Naomi Long and Alliance
